questions.question: What is the maximum number of shareholders an S corporation may have?
questions.explanation: An S corporation is limited to 100 shareholders. However, members of a family (up to six generations) can elect to be treated as one shareholder for this purpose.
questions.tip: S corp = 100 shareholder limit. Family members can count as one.

questions.question: Which of the following may be a shareholder of an S corporation?

options.B: A C corporation
options.C: A nonresident alien

questions.explanation: S corporation shareholders must be individuals, estates, certain trusts, or tax-exempt organizations. Partnerships, corporations, and nonresident aliens cannot be S corporation shareholders.
questions.tip: S corp shareholders: Individuals, estates, certain trusts, 501(c)(3)s. NO corps, partnerships, or NRAs.

questions.question: An S corporation may have:

options.B: Voting and nonvoting common stock
options.C: Multiple classes with different economic rights

questions.explanation: An S corporation can have only one class of stock. However, differences in voting rights alone do not create a second class of stock. Common stock with different voting rights is permitted as long as economic rights (distributions and liquidation) are identical.
questions.tip: S corp = one class of stock. Voting differences OK, but economic rights must be identical.

questions.question: To be effective for the current tax year, Form 2553 (S corporation election) must be filed by:

options.A: The first day of the tax year
options.B: The 15th day of the 3rd month of the tax year
options.C: The last day of the tax year

questions.explanation: An S election must be filed no later than the 15th day of the 3rd month of the tax year to be effective for that year (March 15 for calendar-year corps). If filed late, the election is generally effective for the following tax year.
questions.tip: S election due by 3/15 for calendar year. Late = effective next year.

questions.question: In general, an S corporation:

options.A: Pays corporate income tax on its earnings
options.B: Passes income and losses through to shareholders
options.C: Is taxed as a partnership for all purposes

questions.explanation: An S corporation is a pass-through entity. It generally does not pay federal income tax; instead, income, losses, deductions, and credits pass through to shareholders who report them on their individual returns.
questions.tip: S corp = pass-through. No entity-level tax (usually). Income flows to shareholders' 1040s.

questions.question: A calendar-year S corporation's tax return (Form 1120-S) is due on:

options.B: April 15
options.C: September 15

questions.explanation: S corporation returns are due on the 15th day of the 3rd month following the close of the tax year. For a calendar-year S corporation, this is March 15. This matches the partnership return deadline and allows shareholders to receive K-1s before the April 15 individual filing deadline.
questions.tip: S corps and partnerships: March 15. C corps and individuals: April 15.

questions.question: Tom contributes $50,000 cash and property with a basis of $30,000 (FMV $40,000) to a new S corporation for 100% of its stock. What is Tom's initial stock basis?
questions.explanation: In a Section 351 exchange (which applies to S corporations), the shareholder's basis in stock received equals the basis of property contributed. Tom's basis is $50,000 cash + $30,000 property basis = $80,000. The FMV of property is irrelevant for basis purposes.
questions.tip: Stock basis = basis of contributed cash + property. FMV doesn't matter in Section 351.

questions.conceptTested: Basis adjustments for income and distributions
questions.question: Sara has a beginning stock basis of $25,000 in an S corporation. Her share of ordinary income is $15,000, tax-exempt income is $3,000, and she received distributions of $10,000. What is Sara's ending stock basis?
questions.explanation: S corp stock basis is adjusted as follows: Beginning basis ($25,000) + ordinary income ($15,000) + tax-exempt income ($3,000) - distributions ($10,000) = $33,000. Tax-exempt income increases basis even though it's not taxable.
questions.tip: S corp basis: + income (taxable and tax-exempt), + contributions, - distributions, - losses.

questions.question: Mike has stock basis of $20,000 and debt basis of $10,000 in an S corporation. His share of the S corporation's ordinary loss is $35,000. What amount of loss may Mike deduct?
questions.explanation: S corporation losses are limited to the shareholder's basis in stock plus direct loans to the corporation. Mike can deduct losses up to $20,000 stock basis + $10,000 debt basis = $30,000. The remaining $5,000 loss is suspended and carries forward indefinitely.
questions.tip: S corp loss limit = stock basis + debt basis. Excess suspended, carries forward indefinitely.

questions.question: An S corporation with no accumulated E&P (always been an S corp) distributes cash to shareholders. The distribution is treated as:

options.A: A dividend to the extent of current E&P
options.B: A tax-free return of basis, then capital gain
options.C: Ordinary income

questions.explanation: For an S corporation with no accumulated E&P from C corporation years, distributions are tax-free to the extent of stock basis (return of capital) and any excess is treated as capital gain from the sale of stock.
questions.tip: S corp distributions (no C corp E&P): First reduce basis (tax-free), then capital gain.

questions.question: The built-in gains (BIG) tax applies when:

options.A: Any S corporation sells appreciated assets
options.B: A C corporation converts to an S corporation and sells appreciated assets within 5 years
options.C: An S corporation has passive investment income
options.D: A shareholder sells S corporation stock at a gain

questions.explanation: The BIG tax applies to S corporations that were formerly C corporations and recognize built-in gains (appreciation that existed at conversion) within the recognition period (5 years under current law). The tax is at the highest corporate rate (21%).
questions.tip: BIG tax: C-to-S conversions only. 5-year recognition period. Tax on appreciation at conversion.

questions.question: A shareholder-employee of an S corporation who performs services must:

options.B: Receive reasonable compensation as wages subject to payroll taxes
options.C: Take a minimum of 50% of profits as salary
options.D: Pay self-employment tax on all S corporation income

questions.explanation: Shareholder-employees must receive reasonable compensation for services rendered, which is subject to payroll taxes (FICA). Unlike partners, S corporation shareholders do not pay self-employment tax on their share of pass-through income, creating an incentive to minimize salary.
questions.tip: S corp shareholder-employees need reasonable salary (with FICA). Pass-through income = no SE tax.

questions.conceptTested: Items that must be separately stated
questions.question: Which of the following must be separately stated on an S corporation's Schedule K-1?

options.B: Officer compensation
options.C: Net short-term capital gain

questions.explanation: Items that could affect shareholders differently must be separately stated. Capital gains and losses are separately stated because they retain their character when passed through. Shareholders may have different capital loss carryovers or tax situations affecting the treatment.
questions.tip: Separately stated: Capital gains/losses, Section 1231, charitable, tax-exempt income, etc.

questions.question: The Accumulated Adjustments Account (AAA) is relevant for an S corporation that:

options.A: Has always been an S corporation
options.B: Has accumulated E&P from C corporation years
options.C: Has more than 50 shareholders
options.D: Elects to be taxed as a partnership

questions.explanation: The AAA is most relevant when an S corporation has accumulated E&P from years it was a C corporation. The AAA tracks previously taxed S corporation income and determines whether distributions come from tax-free AAA or taxable accumulated E&P.
questions.tip: AAA matters when S corp has old C corp E&P. AAA distributions first (tax-free), then E&P (dividend).

questions.question: Which event would cause an involuntary termination of an S corporation election?

options.A: The corporation has a loss for three consecutive years
options.B: A shareholder transfers stock to a nonresident alien
options.C: The corporation opens a foreign branch

questions.explanation: The S election terminates when the corporation ceases to meet eligibility requirements. A nonresident alien cannot be an S corporation shareholder, so a transfer to an NRA terminates the election. There are no revenue limits for S corporations.
questions.tip: S election terminates: NRA shareholder, 101+ shareholders, ineligible trust, 2nd class of stock.

questions.question: An S corporation with accumulated E&P is subject to the excess net passive income tax if passive investment income exceeds what percentage of gross receipts?
questions.explanation: An S corporation with accumulated E&P from C corporation years is subject to an entity-level tax on excess net passive income if passive investment income exceeds 25% of gross receipts. If this occurs for three consecutive years, the S election is terminated.
questions.tip: Passive income tax: >25% passive income + old C corp E&P = tax. 3 years = S election ends.

questions.question: Health insurance premiums paid by an S corporation for a 2% shareholder-employee are:

options.A: Fully excludable from the shareholder's income
options.B: Included in the shareholder's W-2 wages but deductible for AGI
options.C: Deductible only as an itemized deduction

questions.explanation: Health insurance for 2%+ shareholder-employees must be included in their W-2 wages. However, the shareholder can claim a deduction for AGI for self-employed health insurance (assuming eligibility requirements are met). The net effect is similar to self-employed treatment.
questions.tip: 2%+ S corp shareholders = treated like partners. Health premiums on W-2, then deduction for AGI.

questions.question: In adjusting an S corporation shareholder's stock basis, which item is applied first?

options.B: Nondeductible expenses
options.C: Income items

questions.explanation: The order for adjusting S corporation stock basis is: (1) increase for income items (including tax-exempt), (2) decrease for distributions, (3) decrease for nondeductible expenses, (4) decrease for losses and deductions. This order maximizes the amount of tax-free distributions.
questions.tip: Basis order: Income first (+), then distributions (-), then expenses (-), then losses (-).

questions.question: For an S election to be valid, consent must be obtained from:

options.B: Shareholders owning more than 50% of the stock
options.C: All shareholders
options.D: Only shareholders who are U.S. citizens

questions.explanation: All shareholders must consent to an S election. This includes any shareholders who held stock during the portion of the year before the election. Community property rules may require both spouses to consent even if only one is the shareholder of record.
questions.tip: S election = unanimous consent. ALL shareholders must agree, including pre-election shareholders.

questions.question: A Qualified Subchapter S Subsidiary (QSub) must be:

options.A: Owned at least 80% by an S corporation
options.B: 100% owned by an S corporation
options.C: Owned by multiple S corporations

questions.explanation: A QSub must be a domestic corporation that is 100% owned by an S corporation parent and not an ineligible corporation. The QSub election causes the subsidiary to be disregarded for tax purposes, with all assets and operations treated as part of the parent S corporation.
questions.tip: QSub = 100% S corp owned. Treated as disregarded entity (part of parent S corp).

questions.question: An S corporation's income is generally allocated to shareholders based on:

options.A: Stock ownership at year end only
options.B: Stock ownership at the beginning of the year
options.C: Per-share, per-day ownership throughout the year

questions.explanation: S corporation income is allocated on a per-share, per-day basis. Each share of stock is allocated an equal portion of each item for each day of the year. When stock is sold mid-year, income is allocated between seller and buyer based on days of ownership.
questions.tip: S corp income = per-share, per-day. Selling shareholder taxed on pre-sale days.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder's debt basis that was reduced by losses is restored by:

options.B: Net income increases (after restoring stock basis to zero)
options.C: Capital contributions

questions.explanation: When losses reduce debt basis, it is restored by subsequent net income increases—but only after stock basis has been restored to zero. Debt basis is restored before additional stock basis increases occur. Capital contributions increase stock basis, not debt basis.
questions.tip: Restore debt basis with income ONLY after stock basis hits zero. Debt basis restored first.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder's deductible loss is subject to which limitations in this order?

options.B: Basis, at-risk, passive activity
options.C: Passive activity, basis, at-risk

questions.explanation: S corporation losses are subject to three limitations in this order: (1) stock and debt basis, (2) at-risk amount, and (3) passive activity rules. A loss must clear each hurdle before the next applies. Amounts failing any test are suspended and carried forward.
questions.tip: Loss limitation order: BASIS → AT-RISK → PASSIVE. Remember: BAP (like a baseball bat sound).

questions.question: An S corporation has AAA of $50,000 and accumulated E&P of $30,000. It distributes $70,000 to its sole shareholder with stock basis of $60,000. How is the distribution characterized?

options.B: $50,000 tax-free, $20,000 dividend
options.C: $50,000 tax-free, $20,000 capital gain

questions.explanation: Distributions come first from AAA (tax-free to extent of stock basis), then from accumulated E&P (dividend), then return of basis (tax-free), then capital gain. Here: $50,000 from AAA (tax-free, reduces stock basis to $10,000), $20,000 from E&P (taxable dividend).
questions.tip: With C corp E&P: AAA first (tax-free), then E&P (dividend), then basis, then gain.

questions.question: Jan has beginning stock basis of $40,000. Her S corp K-1 shows: ordinary income $25,000, tax-exempt interest $2,000, charitable contributions $3,000, and Section 179 expense $5,000. She received $15,000 cash distribution. What is Jan's ending stock basis?
questions.explanation: Beginning basis: $40,000. Add: ordinary income ($25,000) + tax-exempt interest ($2,000) = $67,000. Subtract: distributions ($15,000) = $52,000. Subtract: charitable ($3,000) + Section 179 ($5,000) = $44,000. Note: charitable and Section 179 are separately stated items that reduce basis.
questions.tip: Both deductible AND nondeductible items reduce basis. Track separately stated items.

questions.question: An S corporation that was a C corporation until 3 years ago sells land with a built-in gain of $100,000 (it had $150,000 appreciation at conversion, now sold for $200,000 gain). What is the BIG tax?
questions.explanation: The BIG tax applies to built-in gains recognized within 5 years of conversion. The built-in gain at conversion was $150,000, but only $100,000 was built-in at conversion (the question states $100,000 built-in gain). BIG tax = $100,000 × 21% = $21,000. Post-conversion appreciation is not subject to BIG tax.
questions.tip: BIG tax = built-in gain at conversion × 21%. Only conversion-date appreciation taxed.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder has $0 stock basis and $5,000 suspended loss from last year. This year, her share of ordinary income is $8,000 and she made a $2,000 capital contribution. How much suspended loss can she deduct?
questions.explanation: The capital contribution ($2,000) and ordinary income ($8,000) increase stock basis to $10,000. This provides sufficient basis to deduct the $5,000 suspended loss. After deducting the loss, remaining basis is $5,000 ($10,000 - $5,000). She can deduct the entire suspended loss.
questions.tip: Suspended losses used when basis becomes available. New income + contributions create room.

questions.question: When an S corporation election terminates, the post-termination transition period (PTTP) allows:

options.A: Distributions from AAA to be treated as tax-free for approximately one year
options.B: The corporation to continue filing Form 1120-S
options.C: Shareholders to continue using pass-through losses indefinitely
options.D: A new S election to be made immediately

questions.explanation: The PTTP is generally the longer of (1) one year after termination or (2) the due date for the last S corporation return (including extensions). During this period, distributions from the former AAA are treated as tax-free return of basis. Suspended losses can also be deducted if basis is increased.
questions.tip: PTTP = ~1 year after S termination. Allows tax-free AAA distributions and suspended loss use.

questions.question: Which loan provides debt basis to an S corporation shareholder?

options.A: A bank loan guaranteed by the shareholder
options.B: A direct loan from the shareholder to the S corporation
options.C: A loan from the S corporation to the shareholder
options.D: A loan from another shareholder to the S corporation

questions.explanation: Only direct loans from the shareholder to the corporation provide debt basis. Guaranteeing corporate debt does not create basis (unlike partnerships). Loans from the corporation to shareholder and loans from other shareholders do not provide basis.
questions.tip: S corp debt basis: DIRECT loans from shareholder only. Guarantees don't count (unlike partnerships).

questions.question: Which item affects the Accumulated Adjustments Account (AAA)?

options.B: Ordinary business income
options.C: Federal taxes related to C corporation years
options.D: Life insurance proceeds received on key person policy

questions.explanation: AAA is adjusted for taxable income/loss items and nondeductible expenses related to taxable income, but NOT for tax-exempt income or expenses related to tax-exempt income. Tax-exempt items affect Other Adjustments Account (OAA). Ordinary business income increases AAA.
questions.tip: AAA = taxable items only. Tax-exempt goes to OAA. AAA can go negative.

questions.question: An Electing Small Business Trust (ESBT) that holds S corporation stock is taxed on its S corporation income at:

options.B: The beneficiaries' marginal rates
options.C: The highest individual marginal rate

questions.explanation: The S corporation portion of an ESBT is taxed at the highest individual marginal rate (currently 37%). This is because the income cannot be distributed to beneficiaries while retaining its S corporation character. The ESBT provides flexibility but at a tax cost.
questions.tip: ESBT S corp income = highest individual rate (37%). Separate S portion taxed at trust level.

questions.conceptTested: QBI deduction for S corp shareholders
questions.question: An S corporation shareholder's qualified business income (QBI) deduction under Section 199A is generally:

options.B: Limited to 20% of the shareholder's taxable income
options.C: The lesser of 20% of QBI or 20% of taxable income (minus net capital gains)
options.D: Not available to S corporation shareholders

questions.explanation: The Section 199A deduction is taken at the shareholder level, not the entity level. It equals 20% of qualified business income, limited to the greater of (1) 50% of W-2 wages or (2) 25% of W-2 wages plus 2.5% of qualified property, and cannot exceed 20% of taxable income minus net capital gains.
questions.tip: Section 199A: 20% of QBI, taken on shareholder's 1040. Subject to W-2/property and TI limits.

questions.question: If an S corporation's election is inadvertently terminated, the IRS may grant relief if:

options.A: The corporation pays a penalty of $10,000
options.B: The terminating event is corrected within 3 years
options.C: The termination was inadvertent, the event is corrected, and all parties agree to IRS adjustments
options.D: The corporation had fewer than 50 shareholders

questions.explanation: The IRS may grant relief for inadvertent terminations under Section 1362(f) if: (1) the termination was inadvertent, (2) steps are taken to correct the problem within a reasonable time, and (3) the corporation and all affected shareholders agree to be treated as the IRS prescribes.
questions.tip: Inadvertent termination relief: Must be unintentional, corrected promptly, and parties agree to IRS terms.

questions.question: When can an S corporation use the 'closing of the books' method to allocate income instead of the per-share, per-day method?

options.B: Only when all shareholders consent and there's a qualifying disposition
options.C: Only in the first year of the S election
options.D: When the corporation has more than 50 shareholders

questions.explanation: The closing of the books method may be elected when there is a qualifying disposition (sale or complete termination of interest) and all affected shareholders consent. This method allocates actual income/loss to periods before and after the disposition rather than using per-share, per-day.
questions.tip: Closing the books: Needs qualifying disposition + all affected shareholders' consent.

questions.conceptTested: C to S conversion LIFO tax
questions.question: A C corporation using LIFO inventory converts to an S corporation. The LIFO recapture tax is:

options.B: Paid in the last C corporation year, with tax spread over 4 years
options.C: Avoided entirely upon conversion
options.D: Paid by shareholders in their first S corporation year

questions.explanation: When a C corporation using LIFO converts to an S corporation, it must include the LIFO recapture amount (excess of FIFO value over LIFO value) in income in its last C corporation year. The resulting tax is paid over 4 years (25% per year). Stock basis is increased by the recapture amount.
questions.tip: LIFO recapture on C-to-S: Include in last C year, pay tax over 4 years. Stock basis increases.
